metadata.sermon_title: The Song Of Moses And The Song Of The Lamb
metadata.sermon_start_end: I want to talk with you a little while tonight on the song of Moses and the song of the Lamb. Our Scripture is from the fifteenth chapter of Revelation [...] In God's own time, the sun will shine in an unclouded sky. In God's own time!
metadata.liturgical_context: Evening service with multiple choirs present
metadata.historical_context: Delivered in the mid-1980s (references to Reagan as president and the 25th anniversary of the 1960s civil rights movements). Context of Black homiletic tradition in America.
metadata.notes: The sermon bridges the Exodus narrative with apocalyptic hope, utilizing the 'Black Manifesto' style of social critique and spiritual ecstasy.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon excels in sensory imagery, particularly in the auditory and tactile domains. Taylor moves beyond abstract concepts of 'deliverance' to the 'drumbeat' of music and the 'thunder' of chariot wheels. He paints the Red Sea scene with cinematic detail, allowing the hearer to feel the 'precipitous walls' and see the 'dust from sandals.' The imagery is not merely decorative; it serves as a vehicle for the 'reframing' Cilliers describes, turning a historical text into a present reality. The metaphor of 'masks' for evil effectively illustrates the elusive nature of systemic injustice. The imagery of the 'shacking up' between politics and religion is jarring but rhetorically potent, breaking through conventional religious decorum to create a new perception of reality.
quotes: The church has marched for twenty centuries to the drumbeat of its music.
As those chariot wheels rang against the rocks, that threatening murmur grew into a louder volume until finally it was a thunder.
Like Mardi Gras time, it keeps changing masks. It's hard to tell who it is because they put down one mask and pick up another.
strengths: Strong use of 'show, don't tell' in the Exodus narrative.
Original and culturally grounded metaphors (Mardi Gras masks, shacking up).
Vivid sensory details that evoke the 'stench' and 'sound' of the struggle.
improvement_points: Some metaphors, like 'Bible beaters,' border on cliché.
The transition to the 'arithmetic book' metaphor feels slightly less sophisticated than the previous imagery.
Could incorporate more olfactory or gustatory imagery to round out the sensory experience.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: Strongly weighted toward 'showing.' Taylor reconstructs the scene at the Red Sea so the congregation 'hears' the Egyptians before they see them.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: Taylor demonstrates a high degree of stewardship of language, avoiding 'Canaanite' jargon in favor of precise, evocative English. He defines the 'language of the soul' with poetic precision. However, there is a deliberate use of colloquialisms ('shacking up', 'Bible beaters') which, while rhetorically effective in his tradition, sacrifices some 'sober beauty' for prophetic edge. His analysis of social statistics (single-parent families, prison populations) shows a commitment to naming reality precisely rather than hiding behind theological platitudes. The language is 'loving' in the McEntyre sense, as it refuses to ignore the 'raw and hurting' emotions of the ghetto.
quotes: Music is the language which the soul turns to when ordinary speech will not carry the weight of what is felt.
It is an ugly liaison, a 'shacking up' between the political right and the religious right.
I am not talking now about the injustice—yes, it is there—I am talking about how we destroy ourselves.
strengths: Nuanced description of the 'raw' emotions in music.
Clarity in connecting theological themes to economic and social data.
improvement_points: The critique of the President, while framed respectfully, uses slightly repetitive 'actor' tropes.
Some sentences in the social critique section become slightly list-heavy.
Occasional use of 'well-ordered' academic references could be better integrated into the oral flow.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Minimal religious jargon; theological terms like 'principalities and powers' are contextualized within a cosmic struggle.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: This is the sermon's greatest aesthetic strength. Taylor utilizes the 'musicality' Immink and Grözinger advocate for. The text is replete with parallelism, alliteration, and a rhythmic cadence that builds toward the 'climax' of the 'Lamb's song.' The repetition of 'In God's own time' creates a liturgical rhythm that functions as a performance. The sentence structure varies from short, staccato commands ('Use it!', 'Do something!') to long, flowing 'legato' descriptions of the cosmic battle. It is clearly a text written for the ear, not the eye, embodying the 'oral event' of the worship service.
quotes: Takes the Lord to straighten us out. Takes the Lord to pick us up. Takes the Lord to put us on the right road.
The world shivered on its axis and trembled on its foundation.
In God's own time, the clouds will pass away. In God's own time, the sun will shine in an unclouded sky. In God's own time!
strengths: Masterful use of anaphora and epistrophe.
Rhythmic build-up that mirrors the 'drumbeat' mentioned in the text.
Excellent variation in sentence length to control the emotional tempo.
improvement_points: The middle section regarding General Motors slightly breaks the rhythmic flow established earlier.
The transition from the 'black Mennonite scholar' anecdote is a bit abrupt.
None; the musicality is a benchmark for the genre.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Pure oral language. The text breathes and pulses with a natural cadence intended for proclamation.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The poetics of the sermon are exceptionally strong, characterized by a rhythmic, musical quality that honors the Black homiletic tradition. Taylor uses language not just to inform, but to evoke an atmosphere of struggle and triumph. His imagery is concrete and cinematic, successfully 'showing' the biblical narrative. While he occasionally employs sharp colloquialisms that disrupt a 'sober' aesthetic, these serve the 'reframing' of the gospel in a specific socio-political context. The stewardship of language is evident in his refusal to use vague jargon, opting instead for words that carry the 'weight of what is felt.'

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a clear 'Homiletical Plot' as described by Lowry. It begins with an equilibrium (the music of the choirs), introduces an 'upsetting' (the threat of the Egyptians/the threat of modern evil), and moves toward a turning point (the Red Sea deliverance). There is a second, larger arc moving from the 'Song of Moses' (earthly deliverance) to the 'Song of the Lamb' (cosmic victory). The tension is sustained by moving from the 'murmur' of chariots to the 'silence in heaven.' However, the transition into the 'social critique' section (General Motors, single parents) feels like a secondary plot that momentarily distracts from the primary narrative movement.
quotes: But when the economists of Pharaoh began totaling up what they were losing... they decided they would rather have the afflictions.
It looked for a little while as if God had lost.
But when the light came back on and the earth had righted itself, God's grip held and hell's grip loosened.
strengths: Effective use of 'delayed resolution' in the Red Sea narrative.
Strong 'upsetting of equilibrium' by identifying modern 'Egyptians'.
improvement_points: The 'social critique' section could be more organically woven into the 'Song of Moses' arc.
The conclusion, while powerful, is somewhat predictable in its 'every valley' imagery.
The 'arithmetic book' analogy at the end is a bit of a 'low-energy' moment in an otherwise high-tension arc.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey that moves from the 'now' of historical struggle to the 'not yet' of cosmic victory.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is a textbook example of Cilliers' 'reframing.' Taylor does not simply repeat the Exodus story; he reframes the 'Egyptians' as modern economic forces and political alliances. He respects the 'strangeness' of the text (the shepherd's staff) while making it immediately operative for a congregation facing 'the destruction of a race.' The synthesis is creative: the 'Song of Moses' is not an old song, but a song for the 'now.' He avoids the pitfall of making the text a mere springboard; the biblical narrative provides the actual 'cue and clue' for the contemporary struggle.
quotes: Evil does not give up easily. Like Mardi Gras time, it keeps changing masks.
The Lord delivers us now... He will help us when we cry out now. Now!
It is that huge struggle which gives cue and clue to our little struggle.
strengths: Brilliant 'reframing' of Pharaoh's chariots as economic 'slave masters'.
Organic connection between the 'raw emotions' of the ghetto and the 'screaming' music of the struggle.
Honors the biblical text's historical particularity while asserting its present power.
improvement_points: The connection to the Japanese 'Toyota' partnership feels dated and slightly forced in a theological context.
The leap from 'Moses' to 'single-parent families' is a sharp turn that could use more 'connective tissue'.
Could explore the 'Song of the Lamb' context in Revelation with as much detail as the Exodus context.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: Yes. Reality is reframed from a story of 'black destruction' to a story of 'divine deliverance'.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: In terms of Stark's 'open work of art,' the sermon is somewhat monovalent. It has a very clear, almost coercive 'happy ending' (In God's own time). While it acknowledges the 'ambivalence of existence' (the raw hurt, the silence in heaven), it resolves these tensions quite decisively through the 'peek at the last page.' The hearer is invited into a victory, but there is little room for the 'resistance' or 'doubt' to remain at the end. It is a sermon of 'consolatio' (consolation) that seeks to close the wound with the balm of the Lamb's victory, which is aesthetically powerful but structurally 'closed.'
quotes: The old account is settled. It has all been straightened out, fixed, settled.
I know how it's going to come out.
Somewhere and somehow in God's own time, every valley will be lifted up.
strengths: Provides profound 'consolatio' for a suffering community.
Acknowledges the 'raw and hurting' reality before offering the solution.
The 'silence in heaven' provides a brief moment of aesthetic openness and mystery.
improvement_points: The 'arithmetic book' analogy makes the mystery of God's providence seem a bit too 'pre-calculated'.
The ending is very traditional; an open question might have invited more 'appropriation' by the hearer.
The 'fixed, settled' language leaves little room for the 'not yet' tension Cilliers advocates for.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: Predominantly monovalent/closed. It is a 'victory' sermon that leaves little room for lingering questions.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetic structure is a well-crafted narrative journey. Taylor effectively uses the 'Homiletical Plot' to move from the anxiety of the 'Egyptians' to the triumph of the 'Lamb.' His integration of text and context is a masterclass in 'reframing,' making the ancient Exodus a living reality for his 20th-century audience. While the structure is somewhat 'closed'—favoring a decisive resolution over lingering mystery—this fits the 'consolatio' purpose of the Reformed-Black tradition. The dramaturgy is designed to move the congregation from 'lament' to 'praise,' a movement he achieves with significant rhetorical force.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon largely avoids religious kitsch by grounding its hope in 'raw and hurting' reality. Taylor does not offer 'cheap grace'; he speaks of the 'stench' of the struggle and the 'destruction of a race.' However, the ending's reliance on familiar 'happy ending' tropes (the sun shining in an unclouded sky) flirts with sentimentalism. What saves it from kitsch is the 'authentic depth' of the middle section, where he acknowledges the 'silence in heaven' and the 'awful cry' of dereliction. He sustains the 'pain of suffering' long enough for the comfort to feel earned rather than manufactured.
examples_of_kitsch: The 'arithmetic book' analogy simplifies the mystery of faith into a 'peek at the answers'.
The final 'unclouded sky' imagery is a standard homiletical cliché.
authentic_moments: The description of the 'scream' in the music of the ghetto.
The reflection on the 'silence in heaven' for a half hour during the crucifixion.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: To increase depth, avoid the 'arithmetic book' metaphor and allow the 'unclouded sky' to remain slightly more 'veiled' in the mystery of God's timing.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: Taylor opens a significant 'space for grace' by emphasizing that the power is not in the 'staff' or the 'talent' but in 'God going into action.' This is a strongly Reformed aesthetic: the 'sober beauty' of a 'piece of wood' becoming a tool for God. He resists 'moralization' by stating that 'it takes the Lord to straighten us out.' However, the space is somewhat narrowed by the very specific political and social 'frames' he applies, which might 'close' the space for hearers who don't fit that specific socio-political context. Overall, the 'vertical dimension' of God's intervention remains the primary focus.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: Tensions are sustained through the 'Friday' of the cross but resolved perhaps too quickly in the 'Sunday' of the Lamb.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: The 'silence in heaven' respects mystery; the 'arithmetic book' explains it away.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails. Even the social critique is framed as a need for God's 'straightening out' rather than a mere 'to-do' list.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: Maintain the tension of the 'not yet' longer in the conclusion to allow the 'space' to feel more expansive.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically robust example of the Black Homiletic tradition, blending the 'musicality' of language with the 'reframing' of biblical narrative. Taylor's greatest strength lies in his 'stewardship of language'—he uses words that carry the 'weight of what is felt' and avoids the 'Canaanite' jargon that often plagues religious discourse. The sermon functions as a 'performance' (Immink), where the 'holy happens' through the rhythmic build-up of the prose. Aesthetically, it moves from the 'micro' (the sound of chariot wheels) to the 'macro' (the cosmic battle between light and darkness) with ease. While it leans toward a 'closed' structure that resolves tension through traditional 'consolatio' tropes, it avoids the 'kitsch' of cheap comfort by rooting its hope in the 'raw' reality of racial and social struggle. The 'Space for Grace' is clearly defined: it is not the preacher's talent, but God's 'winds' and 'water' that deliver. The sermon is a 'living work' that invites the hearer to 'march' to the drumbeat of a hope that has 'peeked at the last page.'
strengths_top_3: Masterful 'reframing' of the Exodus narrative for a contemporary context.
Vivid, sensory imagery that 'shows' rather than 'tells'.
improvement_points_top_3: Reduce reliance on 'happy ending' clichés in the conclusion.
Better integration of the 'social critique' section into the primary narrative arc.
Avoid simplifying metaphors like the 'arithmetic book' to preserve mystery.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits Johan Cilliers (Reframing/Space for Grace) and Paul Scott Wilson (Imagery/Four Pages/Show don't tell).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Hearers seeking 'consolatio' amidst systemic struggle; those who respond to oral/aural beauty and narrative drive.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with an 'open ending' to allow the tension of the 'not yet' to linger.
Incorporate more 'sober beauty' in the social critique to match the poetic quality of the biblical sections.
Deepen the 'Song of the Lamb' section with more specific imagery from Revelation.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: Through the lens of homiletic aesthetics, Taylor’s sermon is a high-functioning 'event.' It succeeds not by being 'pretty,' but by being 'true' to both the biblical text and the human condition. It avoids the 'kitsch' of easy answers by honoring the 'scream' in the music of the ghetto, yet it opens a 'space for grace' by pointing consistently to the 'Divine Actor.' It is a model of how 'form is content'—the very rhythm of the sermon communicates the 'marching' hope it proclaims. While a more 'open' structure might have invited more intellectual 'appropriation,' the 'closed' structure of victory serves the immediate aesthetic and spiritual needs of a community in 'struggle.'
